data.name: How Omega-3 Fats Help Your Heart
data.description: Learn how omega-3s support your heart and easy ways to add them to your meals.

data.html:
How Omega-3 Fats Help Your Heart

Omega-3 fats are healthy fats found in fish and some plants. They are known for helping your heart work better and lowering the risk of heart disease. Eating enough omega-3s can make a big difference for your long-term heart health.

What Are Omega-3 Fats?

Omega-3 fats are a type of "good fat" your body needs to stay healthy. There are three main kinds:

  • EPA and DHA — found in fatty fish like salmon, mackerel, and trout
  • ALA — found in plants such as flaxseeds, chia seeds, and walnuts
These fats help your heart, brain, and body in many ways and are an important part of a healthy diet.

How Omega-3s Help Your Heart

  • Lowering blood fats: Omega-3s can lower triglycerides, a type of fat in your blood linked to heart disease.
  • Helping blood pressure: Eating omega-3s often can help lower blood pressure and improve heart health.
  • Keeping blood flowing: Omega-3s help your blood vessels stay open and flexible, making it easier for blood to move through your body.
  • Fighting inflammation: These fats help reduce swelling and inflammation, which protects your heart over time.
  • Balancing your heartbeat: Omega-3s can help prevent irregular heartbeats by supporting your heart's rhythm.

Where to Find Omega-3s

  • Fish: Salmon, sardines, trout, and mackerel are some of the best sources of omega-3s.
  • Plant foods: Flaxseeds, chia seeds, hemp seeds, and walnuts also provide omega-3s, though your body uses them a bit differently.

How to Add Omega-3s to Your Diet

Try to eat fish rich in omega-3s at least twice a week. If you don't eat fish, include plant foods like chia seeds or walnuts in your meals. Some people also take omega-3 supplements, but it's best to talk to a doctor before starting any new supplement.

Omega-3 fats are a simple way to care for your heart. They can lower blood fats, help blood flow, and reduce inflammation. Adding them to your diet is an easy step toward a stronger, healthier heart.
